myopenmath.statement:
Part 1 of 5
A group of economists wants to study the average annual leave among the US and EU workers. Two samples of US and EU workers were obtained independently and analyzed. The sample of 11 US workers had the average annual leave of 17.43 days and the standard deviation 3.217 days. The sample of 17 EU workers had the average annual leave of 26.76 days and the standard deviation 2.714 days. The standard deviation for the first sample appears to be different from the standard deviation of the second sample. Use 10 level of significance to decide whether there is sufficient evidence that the standard deviation of the annual leave of US workers is the same as the standard deviation of the annual leave of EU workers. If normality plots are not provided assume that the samples are from normal populations.
Procedure:
Two means T (pooled) Hypothesis Test
Two means T (non-pooled) Hypothesis Test
Two variances F Hypothesis Test
Two proportions Z Hypothesis Test
Two paired means T Hypothesis Test
Two means Z Hypothesis Test
Assumptions: (select everything that applies)
Simple random samples
Sample sizes are both greater than 30
Paired samples
Population standard deviations are known
Population standard deviation are unknown
Normal populations
Population standard deviations are unknown but assumed equal
The number of positive and negative responses are both greater than 10 for both samples
Independent samples

Part 5 of 5

At 10 significance level we

ul.li: C: Two variances F Hypothesis Test
A: Do not reject the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative.

solution.p: A group of economists wants to study the average annual leave among the US and EU workers. Two samples of US and EU workers were obtained independently and analyzed. The sample of 11 US workers had the average annual leave of 17.43 days and the standard deviation 3.217 days. The sample of 17 EU workers had the average annual leave of 26.76 days and the standard deviation 2.714 days. The standard deviation for the first sample appears to be different from the standard deviation of the second sample. Use 10 level of significance to decide whether there is sufficient evidence that the standard deviation of the annual leave of US workers is the same as the standard deviation of the annual leave of EU workers. If normality plots are not provided assume that the samples are from normal populations.

Procedure: In the question, look for the keywords such as mean/average, proportion/percentage, variance/standard deviation! In this case, we have "the standard deviation of the annual leave" and two populations, thus we are going to perform Two Variances F Hypothesis Test.
Assumptions (select everything that applies): For Two Variances F Hypothesis Test,

ul.li: the samples must be simple random and independent, and
for each sample, the population must be normal;
the assumption "population standard deviations are unknown" is not necessary, but since it is technically satisfied we must select it as well.

solution.p: The null hypothesis \displaystyle{H}_{{0}}: \displaystyle{\frac{{{\sigma_{{1}}^{{2}}}}}{{{\sigma_{{2}}^{{2}}}}}}={1}, where σ₁ is the the standard deviation of the annual leave 1 and σ₂ is the the standard deviation of the annual leave 2 and the units are days;
The alternative hypothesis \displaystyle{H}_{{a}} : \displaystyle{\frac{{{\sigma_{{1}}^{{2}}}}}{{{\sigma_{{2}}^{{2}}}}}}\ne{1} and the test is Two-Tail

Step 3. Compute the value of the test statistic: \displaystyle{f}_{{0}}={\frac{{{{s}_{{1}}^{{2}}}}}{{{{s}_{{2}}^{{2}}}}}}=\frac{{{3.217}^{{2}}}}{{{2.714}^{{2}}}}={1.405} (Round the answer to 3 decimal places) with degrees of freedom \displaystyle{\left({d}{f}{n},{d}{f}{d}\right)}={\left({10},{16}\right)}
To practice finding the test statistic (in this case, \displaystyle{f}_{{0}}={1.405}), please consider the following problem:
Step 4. Testing Procedure: (Round the answers to 3 decimal places)

row.cell: Provide the critical value(s) for the Rejection Region:
Compute the P-value of the test statistic:
left CV is \displaystyle{f}_{{{1}-\frac{\alpha}{{2}}}}={f}_{{0.95}}={0.354} and right CV is \displaystyle{f}_{{\frac{\alpha}{{2}}}}={f}_{{0.05}}={2.494}

solution.p: To practice finding the critical values (in this case, \displaystyle{f}_{{{1}-\frac{\alpha}{{2}}}}={f}_{{0.95}}={0.354} and \displaystyle{f}_{{\frac{\alpha}{{2}}}}={f}_{{0.05}}={2.494}) and drawing the rejection region, please consider the following problem:
To practice finding the P-value (in this case, \displaystyle{2}\min{\left({P}{\left({F}{<}{f}_{{0}}\right)},{P}{\left({F}{>}{f}_{{0}}\right)}\right)}={0.525}), please consider the following problem:

row.cell: Is the test statistic \displaystyle{f}_{{0}}={1.405} in the rejection region, in other words, is \displaystyle{1.405} less than \displaystyle{0.354} or greater than \displaystyle{2.494}?
Is the P-value 0.525 less than the significance level \displaystyle\alpha, in other words, is \displaystyle{0.525}{<}{0.1}?

solution.p: Conclusion: Do not reject the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative.
At 10 significance level we DO NOT have sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative hypothesis.
(StatCrunch) In the menu, select StatVariance StatsTwo SamplesWith Summary and then enter the following:
(TI-83 Plus) Press STATTESTSD:2-SampFTest... and then enter the following:

Among the results, you can find the test statistic and the p-value. When using technology, it is much easier to conduct the test using the p-value approach. Be aware, that technology can help you with computations but you still need to be familiar with the procedure to make the right conclusion!
To practice making the decision based on the P-value, please consider the following problem:
